text: - [Instructor] In this video,

you will learn how to use
Amazon Rekognition Bulk Analysis

to analyze an image dataset,
which will provide you
with the overview of your dataset,

showcasing the distribution
of unsafe images
across moderation taxonomies.

Once you get a good
insights of your images
and know where the problems come from,
you then can utilize
the Rekognition custom moderation feature

to train and adapter,
enhancing moderation accuracy
to meet your specific business needs.
Now, let's get started.

From the Amazon Rekognition
page in the AWS console,
select bulk analysis.

You can see any previous bulk
analysis tasks on this page.

Click start bulk analysis
button to create a new task.
First, you need to choose an adapter
to analyze your dataset with.
By default, no adapter is selected

and the base content
moderation model is used.
If you have a trained adapter in the past,
you can select it from the dropdown list.
Provide a name for the bulk analysis task.
I will call it demo hate symbol job,

because later, the dataset I'm
using is about hate symbol.

You can set your minimum
confidence threshold.
I will leave it 50% as a default setting.

Now you must provide the
image you want to analyze.

You can either import images
from an Amazon S3 bucket

or upload image directly
from your local computer.
I will specify an S3 URI.
If you prefer to use your own KMS key,

for example, your image in
the S3 bucket was encrypted

using a self-managed KMS key,
you can choose it from here
so Rekognition can access the image
from the S3 bucket you provided.
Now click start analysis.
This will start the analysis.

We now have to wait for
the job to complete.
Now the job is completed,
you can see the status become succeeded,

and then we can click on
the job name in the list,

which will bring us to the
bulk analysis detail page.
On the top, it shows general information,
such as name of the job,

the moderation model we
use for this bulk analysis,

and also the input and output
metadata location on S3.
In the middle, we can see in this dataset,

Rekognition flagged 29
images under hate symbol.

And then further scroll down,
we can see the actual images,

and then we see the images
are flaming letters.
They are considered safe,

but the Rekognition flagged
them as hate symbol.
So we want to use this dataset
to train a custom moderation adapter

to improve the accuracy
of hate symbol category.

You can do that, connect to
the custom moderation process,

by clicking on this
verify prediction button,
but before go there, you wanna make sure

to train a custom moderation
adapter for enhanced accuracy.

You wanna make sure you have
at least 20 false positives

or 50 false negatives
for one or more labels.

In my case, I know I
have 29 false positive

under the hate symbol
category, so I'm good to go.

I will click on this
verify prediction button.

It bring me to the custom
moderation annotation page,

where I can provide
human ground truth label

for the images for the
model adapter training.
So let's take a look at the first image.
This is considered a safe image,
but Rekognition flagged it as hate symbol.

So first of all, I will confirm
this is a false positive.
It is not hate symbol,
and also assign the proper label to it.
In this case, it's safe,

so I'm not choosing the other
category, I'm choosing safe.

You can apply the same
setting to multiple images

on the same page by utilizing
the select all images
on the page button.
I will repeat this process
for all the 29 images in my dataset.

Right now, I have annotated
all the 29 images.

You can go click on this
save verification buttons,

which will save the
status of your annotation.
This is especially useful
when you're annotating a larger dataset
so you can save the status in the middle

and then come back later
to resume the task.
Now I can click on train an adapter

to start the custom
moderation adapter training.
I will give the project a name.
In this case, I call it demo,
and then give a name to my adapter.
I'll call it a demo adapter,
a hate symbol false positive adapter,
and you can give it a description.

So by default, Rekognition
will do the auto-split,

split the data into training
and the testing dataset.

You can also specify
separate dataset for training

and the testing if you
already have them ready.

And then there's a data
encryption setting,

similar as bulk analysis, where
you can specify the KMS key,

and use the default setting
confidence threshold,
which is 50%.
You can also enable this auto update.

What it means is, whenever
there's a new base model

available from Rekognition
moderation, by enable this,

Rekognition will automatically
train a new adapter

based on the latest
Rekognition moderation model.

Now I will click on this
button to train adapter,
which will take a few minutes to complete.
We'll come back to check the status.

After training complete, we
can inspect the adapter details

and see its performance by
clicking on the adapter name.

On this page, we can see
the overall performance

and see that the false positive
performance improved by 96%.
We can see the per label performance

for hate symbols under
the false positive tab.

There was an approximately
96% improvement as well.

Down below, you can see all
the images in your dataset
and their predictions.

Inspecting those predictions
will help you to determine

whether you need to focus
when creating a new adapter.

Follow the annotation and
verification best practices
when verifying predictions.
Under the use adapter tab,

you can see how to use
your adapter for inference.
Your unique adapter ID is displayed.
Copy this adapter ID and provide it

to the appropriate operation
when guiding predictions.

A sample AWS CLI combined
and a sample Python code
is provided on this page.
All right, in this video,

you learned how to use
Amazon bulk analysis workflow
to analyze a batch of images
and then train a custom moderation adapter
on the verified bulk analysis predictions.
Thank you for watching.
